meanings.definition: To shoot or fire a weapon.
meanings.sent1: I will skyte the arrow at the target.
meanings.sent2: He likes to skyte cans with his slingshot.
meanings.sent3: The cowboy tried to skyte the apple off the tree but missed.
meanings.sent4: She skyted her words like bullets, hitting her target with precision.
meanings.sent5: The soldier trained hard to skyte accurately in battle.

meanings.definition: A sudden quick movement or action.
meanings.sent1: The cat made a swift skyte across the room.
meanings.sent2: His unexpected skyte surprised everyone in the room.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel's skyte up the tree was quite acrobatic.
meanings.sent4: The skyte of the rabbit into its burrow was a blur of speed.
meanings.sent5: The sudden skyte of the fish out of the water amazed the onlookers.

meanings.definition: A person who is considered to be unreliable or untrustworthy.
meanings.sent1: Be careful, he's known to be a skyte around here.
meanings.sent2: She realized too late that he was a skyte and couldn't be trusted.
meanings.sent3: The fox was called a skyte for always stealing the farmer's chickens.
meanings.sent4: He proved to be a skyte, betraying his friends when they needed him most.
meanings.sent5: The old pirate was known as a skyte among the other sailors.
